text: Everyone, remember you don't have to do the the additive/multiplicative bullet point on HW4. Thanks <@U1L9DD1NY>

<@U1L9DD1NY> <@U1L41DF9D>  The way I understood it, for Deterministic approach:
- With only Trend: Use crosscorr with the data/time variable, and use the same in the Estimate statement with Input 
- With Seasonal + Trend: Create the dummy variables for each unit in the season, and use all the dummy vars in the cross corr. Then use the same in the Estimate statement with Input

Yes I confirmed that! <@U1L0V1X61> if you have trend you need to also include date/time variable in cross corr along with the dummy variables, if you have seasonal and no trend then you'll just use the summary variables
thanks, <@U1L41DF9D> - I think I am starting to get it now :slightly_smiling_face:
Me too!! :smirk: I'm loving time series! :ok_woman:

If we have a season > 12, I know we can no longer use dickey fuller to determine which method to use to make the data stationary. Labarr also said to just try both deterministic and stochastic methods and see which one works best, but how do we know if the data is stationary after trying both of these? Like how do we know we don't need to take another difference or apply a regression line after differencing if we don't have the dickey fuller test to check?
<@U1KRMNVGC> after you take the seasonal difference you can still do the regular adf test for stationarity
